column4: i installed sendmail and played with it for a while. now, every time ubuntu starts, when doing the "Starting basic networking" step, it says something like it can access /etc/mail/sendmail.cf". i unchecked sendmail to start at boot in the "System>Administration>Services" dialog and i even did "sudo apt-get remove sendmail", but ubuntu still tries to do something to /etc/mail/sendmail.cf at boot! what do i do? please help me!
nobody knows how my problem can be solved??
I have not used sendmail, i'm using postfix instead (which is excellent btw) but try "sudo update-rc.d -f sendmail remove"
thanks, i'll try
you may need to "cd /etc/init.d" first but not sure
it deleted a list of "startup links"
yes, that is what that command does so that it does not start (or try to start) during boot
it didnt work! still the same at bootup!
ok. i would install sendmail again, then uninstall it with "sudo apt-get remove --purge sendmail"
--purge removes the config files as well
ok, thanks
it still didnt work!
erhm, what? talk about being obnoxious (sendmail that is)
i guess i'll go reinstall ubuntu then...
there must be an easier way than that.
like what? i dont know any :(

you said that it tries to read a config in the /etc/mail/ directory, right? the network script probably detects the file and then applies it. can't you just remove that file manually if it still exist?
i did delete it, but then it tries to recreate the file as /etc/mail/sendmail.cf.new and fails
i wouldn't know which script is responsible for trying to recreate that file so i'm sortof lost there i'm afraid
then i think i will just reinstall ubuntu tomorrow... have you had any issues with postfix, and can it do the same as sendmail(send mail)?
postfix is fantastic. see !postfix for good tutorials on how to set it up
